title: The history of colonial America

multiple-choice.question: What is a colony?

options.label: A
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people inside their home country.

options.label: B
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people outside their home country and belongs to or is ruled by that home country.

options.label: C
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people outside their home country and doesn't belong to or is ruled by that home country.

options.label: D
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people inside their home country and doesn't belong to or is ruled by that home country.

multiple-choice.question: By the mid-1700s, how many colonies had England set up along the east coast of America?

What was a common way of making money in New England?
What was a unique feature of the Middle Colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: They were all settled by people from England.

options.label: B
options.text: They were the most diverse, home to German, French, Irish, Dutch, and black people.

options.label: C
options.text: They were all settled by people from the Southern Colonies.

options.label: D
options.text: They were all settled by people from the New England Colonies.

multiple-choice.question: What was a major crop grown in the Southern Colonies?
What was a major source of labor in the Southern Colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: African slaves who were taken from their home countries and forced onto plantations.

multiple-choice.question: What was a major reason why the 13 colonies became 13 states?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the diversity of the colonies.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the similarity of the colonies.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the conflicts between the colonies and England.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the conflicts between the colonies.

options.label: C

options.text: B: Ordinary altruists are less self-centered, while extraordinary altruists are more self-centered.

options.label: D

options.text: To prioritize the charity's mission over the donor's experience.

title: The Gauntlet | Think Like A Coder, Ep 8

multiple-choice.question: What problem is Ethic and Hedge facing?

options.label: A
options.text: A problem with the Node of Creation.

options.label: B
options.text: A problem with the Node of Memory.

options.label: C
options.text: A problem with finding the one safe path in the gauntlet of forking paths.

options.label: D
options.text: A problem with the robots in Huxenborg.

multiple-choice.question: What power has the Node of Creation granted Hedge?

options.label: A
options.text: The power to destroy any robot.

options.label: C
options.text: The power to produce slightly smaller versions of himself.

multiple-choice.question: What is recursion?

options.label: B
options.text: A way of repeating actions in a different way than loops.

options.label: C
options.text: A tool used in programming to refer back to itself.

options.label: D
options.text: A way of solving problems that involve self-similarity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "base case" of the recursion in this problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The starting point of the gauntlet of forking paths.

options.label: B
options.text: The point where Hedge produces the first copy of himself.

options.label: C
options.text: The point where the copy that goes the wrong way is destroyed.

options.label: D
options.text: The point where the copy that reaches the artifact radios back the path it took.

multiple-choice.question: What are the instructions that every version of Hedge will follow?

options.label: A
options.text: 1. Move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 2. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right, then repeat everything you just heard.

options.label: B
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right, then repeat everything you just heard.

options.label: C
options.text: 1. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 2. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right.

options.label: D
options.text: 1. When you reach an intersection, move off the conveyor and send new copies down the left and right paths. 2. If you've reached the artifact, radio to your parent whether you got there by going left or right. 3. If you hear anything over the radio, you should radio to your parent whether you got to your spot by going left or right, then repeat everything you just heard.

title: If your hands could smell, you’d be an octopus

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: The importance of setting in a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the author's discussion about the book they finished reading?

options.label: A
options.text: The author is discussing the characters in the book.

options.label: B
options.text: The author is discussing the setting of the book.

options.label: C
options.text: The author is discussing the plot of the book.

options.label: D
options.text: The author is discussing the theme of the book.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the setting can inform the plot and conflict in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting can inform the plot and conflict by providing a backdrop for the story to take place.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can inform the plot and conflict by revealing the characters' emotions and motivations.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting can inform the plot and conflict by creating a mood that influences the characters' actions.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting can inform the plot and conflict by providing a random and unexpected twist.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the author choose a cave as the setting for the story of Odysseus?

options.label: A
options.text: The author chose a cave because it was a convenient and easily accessible location.

options.label: B
options.text: The author chose a cave because it was a dark and foreboding place that fit the mood of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: The author chose a cave because it was a place where Odysseus could easily escape from the Cyclops.

options.label: D
options.text: The author chose a cave because it was a place where the Cyclops could easily find Odysseus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main point about the importance of setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The author is saying that setting is not important in a story.

options.label: B
options.text: The author is saying that setting is only important if it is a central part of the plot.

options.label: C
options.text: The author is saying that setting is crucial in creating the mood and themes of a story.

options.label: D
options.text: The author is saying that setting is only important if it is a physical location.

title: Why do India and China have so many people?

multiple-choice.question: What is the combined population of India and China?
Which two countries have added more than a billion people to their populations over the last 300 years?
What is the main reason why India and China have had a large population for so long?

options.label: B
options.text: Fertile land and good access to fresh water

multiple-choice.question: Which region of the world has been the most densely populated for a really long time?
What is the main reason why countries like Pakistan and Bangladesh have a smaller population compared to India and China?

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of access to fresh water

options.label: B
options.text: Climate change, population growth, and sustainable development

options.label: C
options.text: Economic inequality, social justice, and human rights

title: Where did Earth's water come from?

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of Earth's surface is liquid water?
According to the story of how our solar system formed, why should Earth's surface be "bone dry"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the early inner solar system was too cold for water to exist.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the early inner solar system was too hot for water to exist.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the solar wind would have blasted away any water vapor.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the planet was formed from a cloud of dust and gas that didn't contain water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely source of Earth's water, according to the transcript?
What is a characteristic of the water in carbonaceous chondrite meteorites that matches the water on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: They have fewer heavy hydrogen atoms than Earth water.

options.label: B
options.text: They have the same levels of heavy hydrogen as Earth water.

options.label: C
options.text: They have more heavy hydrogen atoms than Earth water.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no heavy hydrogen atoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the class of stony meteoroids that most commonly strike the Earth?
Why were comets initially considered a likely source of Earth's water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are rich in heavy hydrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they formed out beyond the sun's frost line.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have levels of heavy hydrogen similar to that of Earth water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "frost line" in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The boundary beyond which water can exist in the form of ice.

options.label: B
options.text: The boundary beyond which the solar wind can exist.

options.label: C
options.text: The boundary beyond which the early inner solar system was too hot for water to exist.

options.label: D
options.text: The boundary beyond which the planet was formed from a cloud of dust and gas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely origin of the water that turned our planet into a blue marble?
What is the name of the type of meteorite that is the likely source of Earth's water?
Why were comets ruled out as the source of Earth's water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are rich in heavy hydrogen.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have levels of heavy hydrogen similar to that of Earth water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they formed out beyond the sun's frost line.

title: I am Abraham Lincoln

title: Embrace the Shake - Phil Hansen

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial problem that the artist faced in his pursuit of pointillism?

options.label: A
options.text: He had too many choices in his art supplies.

options.label: B
options.text: He had a single-minded pursuit of pointillism that led to a shake in his hand.

options.label: C
options.text: He was unable to create art due to a lack of inspiration.

options.label: D
options.text: He was paralyzed by the choices he had in his art.

multiple-choice.question: What did the neurologist suggest the artist do to deal with his shake?

options.label: A
options.text: He should try to control the shake by holding the pen tighter.

options.label: C
options.text: He should embrace the shake and see where it takes him.

options.label: D
options.text: He should try to ignore the shake and continue with his art as usual.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's approach to creativity after he began to experiment with different ways to fragment images?

options.label: A
options.text: A: He focused on working with smaller materials and more precise techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: He started working on a larger scale and with bigger materials.

options.label: C
options.text: He began to explore different mediums and techniques to create his art.

options.label: D
options.text: He continued to work with pointillism, but with a focus on control and precision.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's project called that involved creating art with a dollar's worth of supplies?
What was the artist's approach to creating art when he was unable to create due to too many choices?

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to think outside the box and come up with new ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: He focused on working within the limitations he had.

options.label: D
options.text: He tried to ignore the problem and continue with his art as usual.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's project called that involved destroying each piece of art after its creation?
What was the artist's approach to creating art when he had to rely on other people to create the content for the art?

options.label: A
options.text: He focused on working with a small group of people to create the art.

options.label: B
options.text: He relied on a single person to create the art.

options.label: C
options.text: He asked people to call him and share a story with him about a life-changing moment.

options.label: D
options.text: He tried to create the art on his own.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's approach to creating art when he had to destroy it?

options.label: A
options.text: He focused on creating art that was temporary and ephemeral.

options.label: B
options.text: He created art that was destroyed naturally.

options.label: C
options.text: He tried to produce something that didn't actually exist in the first place.

options.label: D
options.text: He continued to create art that was meant to be permanent.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's approach to creating art when he was stuck and unable to come up with new ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to think outside the box and come up with new ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: He focused on working within the limitations he had.

options.label: C
options.text: He continued to show up for the process and try to remind himself of the possibilities.

multiple-choice.question: What was the artist's message to others about creativity and limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: He encouraged people to seize the day and come up with new ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: He reminded people to seize the limitation and work within their constraints.

options.label: C
options.text: He encouraged people to focus on their strengths and avoid their weaknesses.

options.label: D
options.text: He encouraged people to quit when they are stuck and unable to come up with new ideas.
